{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox AM | honorific-prefix = Chief | name = Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti | honorific-suffix = [[Order of the Niger|MON]] | image = 70 year old Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti on her birthday.png | imagesize = | birth_date = {{birth date |df=yes|1900|10|25}} | birth_place = [[Abeokuta]], [[Southern Nigeria Protectorate|Southern Nigeria]]
(now Abeokuta, Ogun State) |occupation = Educator, politician, women's rights activist | spouse = [[Israel Oludotun Ransome-Kuti]] | children={{plainlist| * [[Olikoye Ransome-Kuti]] (son) * [[Beko Ransome-Kuti]] (son) * [[Fela Anikulapo-Kuti]] (son) * Dolapo Ransome-Kuti (daughter) }} | relatives = {{plainlist| * [[Femi Kuti]] (grandson) * [[Seun Kuti]] (grandson) * [[Wole Soyinka]] (nephew) * [[Yemisi Ransome-Kuti]] (niece) }} | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1978|4|13|1900|10|25}} | death_place = [[Lagos]], Nigeria }} [[Chieftain|Chief]] '''Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti''', [[Order of the Niger|MON]] ({{IPAc-en|pron|ˌ|f|ʊ|n|m|i|ˈ|l|aɪ|j|oʊ|_|ˈ|r|æ|n|s|ə|m|_|ˈ|k|uː|t|i}}; 25 October 1900 – 13 April 1978){{Cite web |url=http://nigerianstatesmen.com/?p=77 |title=Funmilayo Ransome Kuti Nigerian Statesmen }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, otherwise known as '''Funmilayo Anikulapo-Kuti''', was a teacher, political campaigner, [[women's rights]] activist and [[Oba (ruler)#Oloye|traditional aristocrat]] in [[Nigeria]]. She served with distinction as one of the most prominent leaders of her generation. She was also the first woman in the country to drive a car.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VMi3AAAAIAAJ&q=|title=The Nigerian woman: her economic and socio-political status in time perspective|author=Modupeolu Faseke|publisher=Agape Publications|year=2001|isbn=978-9-783-5626-53}} Ransome-Kuti's political activism led to her being described as the doyen of [[women in Nigeria|female rights in Nigeria]], as well as to her being regarded as "The Mother of Africa." Early on, she was a very powerful force advocating for the Nigerian woman's [[right to vote]]. She was described in 1947, by the ''[[West African Pilot]]'', as the "Lioness of Lisabi" for her leadership of the women of the [[Egba people]] on a campaign against their arbitrary taxation. That struggle led to the abdication of the high king [[Oba Ademola II]] in 1949.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=7Q8Ix-M8LWcC&pg=PA53&dq=|title=Women's History in Global Perspective, Volumes 2-3|page=53|author=Bonnie G. Smith|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-252-0299-05}} Kuti was the mother of the Nigerian activists [[Fela Anikulapo Kuti]], a musician; [[Beko Ransome-Kuti]], a doctor; and Professor [[Olikoye Ransome-Kuti]], a doctor and health minister.{{Cite web |url=http://jibolu-taiwo-of-egbaland.com/4.html |title=Family tree: jibolu-taiwo-of-egbaland |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713104620/http://jibolu-taiwo-of-egbaland.com/4.html |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} She was also grandmother to musicians [[Seun Kuti]] and [[Femi Kuti]]. She is highly regarded in her native Nigeria for notable acts as an African woman. ==Life== [[File:Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti graduate.png|thumb|Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti, the graduate]] '''Francis Abigail Olufunmilayo Thomas''' was born on 25 October 1900, in [[Abeokuta]], to Chief Daniel Olumeyuwa Thomas and Lucretia Phyllis Omoyeni Adeosolu of the Jibolu-Taiwo family. Her father was a son of a returned slave from [[Sierra Leone]] (see [[Nova Scotian Settlers]]), who traced his ancestral history back to Abeokuta in what is today [[Ogun State]], Nigeria.Margaret Strobel, "Women agitating internationally for change". ''Journal of Women's History''. Baltimore: Summer 2001. Vol. 13, Issue 2; p. 190, 12 pp. He became a member of the [[Anglican]] faith, and soon returned to the homeland of his fellow Egbas. She attended [[Abeokuta Grammar School]] for her secondary education, and later went to England for further studies. She soon returned to Nigeria and became a teacher. On 20 January, 1925, she married the Reverend [[Israel Oludotun Ransome-Kuti|Israel Oludotun, Ransome-Kuti]]. He also defended the commoners of his country, and was one of the founders of both the [[Nigeria Union of Teachers]] and of the Nigerian Union of Students.{{Cite book |last=Johnson-Odim |first=Cheryl |authorlink=|first2=Emma|last2= Mba |editor= |others= |title=For Women and the Nation: Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti of Nigeria |origyear= |url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1997 |publisher=University of Illinois Press |location= |language= |isbn=0-252-06613-8 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= }}. Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti organized literacy classes for Women in the early 1920s and founded a nursery school in the 1930s. She founded the Abeokuta Ladies' Club (ALC) for educated women involved in charitable work in 1942. She also started the social Welfare for Market Women club to help educate working-class women (which formed the first adult education program for women in Nigeria){{Cite web|url=https://zodml.org/discover-nigeria/people/funmilayo-ransome-kuti#.WwVLy4pOnIU|title=Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti|website=ZODML|language=en|access-date=2018-05-23}}. Ransome-Kuti received the national honour of membership in the [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Nigeria|Order of the Niger]] in 1965. The [[University of Ibadan]] bestowed upon her the [[honorary doctorate]] of laws in 1968. She also held a seat in the Western [[House of Chiefs]] of Nigeria as an ''[[Oba (ruler)#Oloye|Oloye]]'' of the [[Yoruba people]]. ==Activism== Throughout her career, she was known as an educator and activist. She and [[Elizabeth Adekogbe]] provided dynamic leadership for women's rights in the 1950s. Ransome-Kuti founded an organization for women in Abeokuta, with a membership tally of more than 20,000 individuals, spanning both literate and illiterate women.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nigerianbiography.com/2015/10/funmilayo-ransome-kuti-biography-and.html|title=Nigerian Biography: Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti. Biography and Activism.|website=www.nigerianbiography.com|access-date=13 May 2016}} ===Women's rights=== Main article: [[Abeokuta Women's Revolt]] [[File:Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti thinks.png|left|thumb|Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti and The Women’s Union of Abeokuta[http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/CI/CI/pdf/publications/frk_en.pdf Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti And The Women’s Union of Abeokuta], Illustrations: Alaba Onajin, Script and text: Obioma Ofoego, UNESCO, 2014.]] Ransome-Kuti launched the organization into public consciousness when she rallied women against price controls that were hurting the market women. Trading was one of the major occupations of women in the [[Western State (Nigeria)|Western Nigeria]] at the time. In 1949, she led a protest against [[Provinces of Nigeria|Native Authorities]], especially against the [[Alake of Egbaland]]. She presented documents alleging abuse of authority by the Alake, who had been granted the right to collect the taxes by his colonial suzerain, the Government of the United Kingdom. He subsequently relinquished his crown for a time due to the affair. She also oversaw the successful abolishing of separate tax rates for women. In 1953, she founded the Federation of Nigerian Women Societies, which subsequently formed an alliance with the [[Women's International Democratic Federation]]. (See also [[National Council of Women's Societies]].) Funmilayo Ransome Kuti campaigned for women's votes. She was for many years a member of the ruling [[National Council of Nigeria and the Cameroons]] (NCNC) party, but was later expelled when she was not elected to a federal parliamentary seat. She was the treasurer and subsequent president of the Western NCNC Women's Association.{{Cite book |last=Sklar|first=Richard L. |title=Nigerian Political Parties: Power in an Emergent African Nation |year=2004 |publisher=Africa Research & Publications |isbn=1-59221-209-3}} After her suspension, her political voice was diminished due to the direction of national politics, as both of the more powerful members of the opposition, [[Awolowo]] and Adegbenro had her support close by. However, she continued her activism.Joyce M. Chadya, "MOTHER POLITICS: Anti-colonial Nationalism and the Woman Question in Africa". ''Journal of Women's History''. Autumn 2003. Vol. 15, Issue 3; p. 153. In the 1950s, she was one of the few women elected to the house of chiefs. At the time, this was one of her homeland's most influential bodies. She founded the Egba or Abeokuta Women's Union along with Eniola Soyinka (her sister-in-law and the mother of the [[Nobel Prize|Nobel Laureate]] [[Wole Soyinka]]). This organisation is said to have once had a membership of 20,000 women. Among other things, Ransome-Kuti organised workshops for illiterate market women.{{Cite web|url=http://www.feministafrica.org/uploads/File/Issue_8/03_issue8_editorial.pdf |title=Editorial: Rethinking Universities I |accessdate=11 July 2009 |author= |last=Mama |first=Amina |authorlink= |author2=Teresa Barnes |format=pdf |work=Feminist Africa |publisher= |location= |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= }} She continued to campaign against taxes and [[price controls]].{{Cite web|url=http://digital.lib.msu.edu/projects/africanjournals/pdfs/glendora%20review/vol2no2/graa002002007.pdf |title=Monuments and metamorphosis |accessdate=11 July 2009 |last=Adeniyi |first=Dapo |authorlink= |format= |work=African Quarterly on the Arts Vol. 2, No. 2}} ===Travel ban=== [[File:Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti and world.png|thumb|Picture from "Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti And The Women’s Union of Abeokuta"]] During the [[Cold War]] and before the independence of her country, Ransome-Kuti travelled widely and angered the Nigerian as well as British and American governments by her contacts with the [[Eastern Bloc]]. This included her travel to the former USSR, Hungary and China, where she met [[Mao Zedong]]. In 1956, her passport was not renewed by the government because it was said that "it can be assumed that it is her intention to influence … women with communist ideas and policies."{{Cite web |url=http://bigissue.co.za/africanews/46478/funmilayo-kuti-30-years-of-absence-9-april-2008 |title=Funmilayo Kuti – 30 Years of Absence |accessdate=11 July 2009 |date=April 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311231136/http://bigissue.co.za/africanews/46478/funmilayo-kuti-30-years-of-absence-9-april-2008 |archive-date=11 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} She was also refused a U.S. visa because the American government alleged that she was a communist. Prior to independence she founded the Commoners Peoples Party in an attempt to challenge the ruling NCNC, ultimately denying them victory in her area. She received 4,665 votes to the NCNC's 9,755, thus allowing the opposition Action Group (which had 10,443 votes) to win. She was one of the delegates who negotiated Nigeria's independence with the British government. ==Death== In old age her activism was overshadowed by that of her three sons, who provided effective opposition to various Nigerian military [[juntas]]. In 1978 Ransome-Kuti was thrown from a third-floor window of her son Fela's compound, a [[commune]] known as the [[Kalakuta Republic]], when it was stormed by one thousand armed military personnel. She lapsed into a coma in February of that year, and died on 13 April 1978, as a result of her injuries.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=57C0d-Nl830C&pg=PA261&dq=|page=261|title=Culture + the State: Nationalisms (Critical Works from the Proceedings of the 2003 Conference at the University of Alberta)|volume=3|author1=Gabrielle Eva Marie Zezulka-Mailloux|author2=James Gifford|publisher=CRC Studio|year=2003|isbn=978-1-551-9514-92}}. ==Proposed N5000 note controversy== On Thursday, 30 August 2012, one of her grandsons, musician [[Seun Kuti]], responded to questions from fans and friends on [[Channels Television]], Nigeria’s platform via Google+. Saying that his grandmother was murdered by the Federal Government, Seun Kuti asked the Federal Government to apologise to his family for the death of Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti, before considering immortalising her by putting her picture on the proposed N5000 note. As of 3 September 2012, the Nigerian government neither responded to his request nor apologized. Several protest groups formed on social media adding pressure for a government apology.{{Cite web|url=http://www.channelstv.com/home/2012/08/31/apologise-for-killing-my-grandmum-before-putting-her-face-on-naira-seun-kuti-tells-fg/|title=Apologise for killing my grandmum before putting her face on naira, Seun Kuti tells FG |publisher=Channels Television, Nigeria |accessdate=4 September 2012}} The N5000 proposal was later withdrawn by the Nigerian government. ==Achievements== *Took part in the pre-independence conferences that laid the groundwork for [[First Nigerian Republic|Nigeria's First Republic]] *One of the women appointed to the native House of Chiefs, serving as an [[Oba (ruler)#Oloye|Oloye]] of the [[Yoruba people]] *Ranking member of the [[National Council of Nigeria and the Cameroons]] *Treasurer and President Western Women Association of the [[National Council of Nigeria and the Cameroons]] *Leader of [[Abeokuta Women's Union]].{{cite journal|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/407888/summary|title=Taxation, Women, and the Colonial State: Egba Women's Tax Revolt |volume=3|number=2|year=2003| author=Judith A. Byfie|publisher=Meridians: feminism, race, transnationalism (Project Muse)}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=HwqQCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA282&dq=Funmilayo+Ransome+Kuti+Abeokuta+Women%27s+revolt&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiNxIK_ldnWAhVoIsAKHeRRCWcQ6AEIMDAC#v=onepage&q=Funmilayo%20Ransome%20Kuti%20Abeokuta%20Women's%20revolt&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of Women in Sub-Saharan Africa|author=Kathleen Sheldon|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2016|isbn=978-1-442-2629-35|page=282}} *Leader of Commoners Peoples Party *Leader of Nigeria Women's Union. *First woman to drive a car in Nigeria *Winner of the [[Lenin Peace Prize]]{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/dec/11/fela-kuti-great-dynasties-ian-sansom|publisher=''The Guardian'' |author=Ian Sansom |date=11 December 2010|title =Great Dynasties: The Ransome-Kutis|accessdate=18 June 2014 }}{{Cite journal |last = Johnson-Odim | first = Cheryl | title = ‘For their freedoms’: The anti-imperialist and international feminist activity of Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti of Nigeria |journal = [[Women's Studies International Forum]], special issue: Circling the Globe: International Feminism Reconsidered, 1910 to 1975 |volume = 32 |issue = 1 |page = 58 |publisher = Elsevier |doi = |date = January–February 2009 |url = http://54.72.213.104/PDFs/AfricanAmazon/Johnson-Odim.pdf }} ==Cultural depiction and legacy== Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti was portrayed in the 2014 film ''[[October 1 (film)|October 1]]'' by [[Deola Sagoe]].{{cite news|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2013/08/late-funmilayo-ransom-kuti-resurrects-in-new-movie-october-1/|title=Late Funmilayo Ransome Kuti resurrects in new movie…’October 1|date=13 August 2013|author=Charles Mgolu|accessdate=13 May 2017|work=The Vanguard}} She is one of the most prominent figures in Nigerian history and inspired women across Nigeria through her brave acts and most notably her fight for women in the country. Some say that she paved the way for women in Nigeria to have better lives. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/CI/CI/pdf/publications/frk_en.pdf Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti And The Women’s Union of Abeokuta], Illustrations: Alaba Onajin, Script and text: Obioma Ofoego, UNESCO, 2014 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071210155735/http://www.cafeafricana.com/Funmilayo%20Ransome-Kuti.html Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti] *[http://www.afrobeatmusic.net/html/fela_bio.html Biography of Fela Anikulapo Kuti (1938–1997)] *Mhairi McAlpine, [http://internationalsocialist.org.uk/index.php/2012/06/women-on-the-left-funmilayo-anikulapo-kuti/ "Women on the Left: Funmilayo Anikulapo-Kuti"], International Socialist Group, 8 June 2012. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ransome-Kuti, Funmilayo}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from Abeokuta]] [[Category:Nigerian women educators]] [[Category:Yoruba educators]] [[Category:Yoruba activists]] [[Category:Nigerian women's rights activists]] [[Category:Nigerian women activists]] [[Category:Deaths from falls]] [[Category:Ransome-Kuti family]] [[Category:20th-century Nigerian politicians]] [[Category:Nigerian feminists]] [[Category:Lenin Peace Prize recipients]] [[Category:Nigerian royalty]] [[Category:Yoruba royalty]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the Niger]] [[Category:Nigerian suffragists]] [[Category:Women's suffrage]] [[Category:People of colonial Nigeria]] [[Category:Nigerian schoolteachers]] [[Category:Violence against women in Nigeria]] [[Category:Yoruba women in politics]] [[Category:Nigerian women in politics]] [[Category:Nigerian women's history]] [[Category:20th-century women politicians]] [[Category:History of Abeokuta]] [[Category:20th-century Nigerian educators]] [[Category:20th-century Nigerian women]]

revision.comment: Copying from [[Category:Romanian male short story writers]] to [[Category:Romanian short story writers]] (non-diffusing) using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = George Diamandy | image = File:Diamandy 1912.JPG | caption = Diamandy in or around 1912 | pseudonym = Georges Diamandy, Giorgio Diamandy, Gh. Despina, Ion Marvila, Ne om | birth_date = February 27, 1867 | birth_place = [[Roșiești|Idrici]] or [[Bârlad]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1917|12|27|1867|2|27}} | death_place = [[North Sea]], off [[Shetland]] | occupation = politician, social scientist, journalist, diplomat, landowner | nationality = Romanian | period = ca. 1887–1916 | genre = [[essay]], [[diary]], [[drama]], [[fantasy literature]], ''[[comédie en vaudeville]]'', [[novella]], [[travel literature]] | subject = | movement = [[Naturalism (literature)|Naturalism]] | signature = | website = }} '''George Ion Diamandy''' or '''Diamandi''', first name also '''Gheorghe''' or '''Georges''' (February 27, 1867 – December 27, 1917), was a Romanian politician, dramatist, social scientist, and archeologist. Although a rich landowner of aristocratic background, he was one of the pioneers of [[revolutionary socialism]] in France and Romania, obtaining international fame as founder of ''L'Ère Nouvelle'' magazine. He was an early affiliate of the [[Romanian Social-Democratic Workers' Party]], but grew disenchanted with its radical policies, and, as a member of its "generous youth" faction, played a major part in dissolving it. With other members of this [[Reformism|reformist]] group, he joined the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]], serving as one of its representatives in [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Chamber]].
Affected by heart disease from childhood, Diamandy had to maintain a low profile in politics, but was a vocal marginal within the National Liberal establishment. From 1910, he invested his energy in literature and cultural activism, chairing the [[National Theater Bucharest]] and later the [[Romanian Writers' Society]]. He was pushed back to the forefront during the early stages [[World War I]], when he supported an alliance with the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]]. He advised [[Prime Minister of Romania|Premier]] [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]] on the matter and was sent on diplomatic missions to the West, helping to cement France's trust for Romania. He fought in the ill-fated [[Romania in World War I|campaign of 1916]], and withdrew to [[Iași]], retaking his seat in Chamber.
During his final years, Diamandy became an advocate of [[democratic socialism]], founding the Iași-based [[Labor Party (Romania)|Labor Party]] and seeking the friendship of [[Socialist Revolutionary Party|Russian Esers]]. The [[October Revolution]] caught him in Russia, but he escaped by way of [[Arkhangelsk]], and died at sea while attempting to reach France.
George Diamandy was the brother and collaborator of diplomat [[Constantin I. Diamandy]], and the posthumous grandfather of writer [[Oana Orlea]]. He is largely forgotten as a dramatist, but endures in cultural memory for his controversial politics and his overall eccentricity.
==Biography==
===Early life=== George Diamandy, the son of landowner Ion "Iancu" Diamandy and Cleopatra Catargiu, was born in [[Roșiești|Idrici]], [[Vaslui County]],<ref name="gc657">Călinescu, p. 657</ref> or, by his own admission, in [[Bârlad]].<ref name="gdy69">Diamandy, p. 69</ref> Several sources, including Diamandy's own account, give his birth date as February 27, 1867<ref name="gdy69"/><ref name="ffmoșierul">{{ro icon}} [[Florin Faifer]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/FAIFERap.html "Moșierul"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', April 2002</ref> ([[George Călinescu]], the literary historian, has October 27).<ref name="gc657"/> His brother, Constantin "Costică", was born in 1870. Constantin and George also had a sister, Margareta, later married Popovici-Tașcă.<ref name="gc657"/>
The Diamandys, of [[Greeks in Romania|Greek]] origins,<ref name="msrdamandy">{{ro icon}} Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/diplomatie-si-scris-familia-diamandy-3043441/ "Diplomație și scris: familia Diamandy"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', February 23, 2007</ref> had made a slow climb into the aristocracy of [[Moldavia]] and, later, the [[Kingdom of Romania]]. One branch of the family, who used the name variant ''Emandi'', produced diplomat [[Theodor Emandi]].<ref name="msrdamandy"/> Iancu rose to high office, serving in [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] and as [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]] of [[Tutova County]].<ref name="msrdamandy"/><ref>Butnaru I, p. 135</ref> His wife Cleopatra belonged to the higher realms of the [[boyar]] aristocracy, and according to politician-memoirist [[Constantin Argetoianu]], had passed her "pride" and "airs" to both her sons.<ref name="abI146"/>
George, who always spoke [[Romanian language|Romanian]] with a thick and archaic [[Moldavian subdialect of Romanian|Moldavian accent]],<ref>Livescu, p. 130; Massoff, pp. 320–321</ref> was first enlisted in school at Bârlad. However, having been infected with [[malaria]], he had to spend much of his childhood taking seaside cures in France.<ref name="gdy69"/> He then returned to study at the United Institutes High School in [[Iași]], where he notably put out a clandestine student magazine, ''Culbecul'' ("The Snail").<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', p. 779; Călinescu, p. 657</ref> As noted by Călinescu, he was "absent-minded and rebellious."<ref name="gc657"/> According to his own account, he was "mediocre", but "read extensively outside the curriculum". He disliked the school and claimed that it gave him [[rheumatism]] and heart problems.<ref name="gdy69"/>
[[File:Frații Diamandy 1890.JPG|thumb|270px|George Diamandy (first from the left, seated) and brother [[Constantin I. Diamandy|Constantin]] (standing behind him), in an 1890 photograph]] His life course was changed by his discovery of socialism and [[proletarian internationalism]], and he soon became their avid promoter. His brother had entirely different opinions in this respect, calling socialism "a farce".<ref>Gorovei, p. 152</ref> George and his best friend [[Arthur Gorovei]] founded their own Socialist Club, which only lasted a few days.<ref>Gorovei, p. 151</ref> Diamandy also published political articles in the review ''[[Contemporanul]]'' (the first one in 1887),<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> following up with similar contributions to ''[[Munca]]'' and [[Raicu Ionescu-Rion]]'s ''Critica Socială''.<ref>Diamandy, p. 69; Petrescu, pp. 80–81, 90–91</ref> He neglected his schoolwork and, in his own words, passed his [[Romanian Baccalaureate|Baccalaureate]] "more than anything because the professors were generous".<ref name="gdy69"/>
Diamandy also developed a passion for archeology, enjoying in particular the books of [[Louis Laurent Gabriel de Mortillet|Gabriel de Mortillet]] and [[Theodor Mommsen]].<ref>Gorovei, pp. 151, 153</ref> He camped out with [[Nicolae Beldiceanu]] in [[Cucuteni]], where he helped on the inventory of the [[Cucuteni-Trypillian culture]].<ref>Călinescu, p. 657; Gorovei, pp. 44–45, 48, 152–153</ref> Diamandy was also a member of the Bârlad National Romanian Committee, which gathered funds and artifacts for the Romanian delegation to the [[Exposition Universelle (1889)|1889 Exposition Universelle]].<ref>Georges Bibesco, ''Exposition universelle 1889. La Roumanie avant-pendant-après'', Imprimerie Typographique J. Kugelmann, Paris, 1890, pp. 370, 385</ref> He was working on a novel in the manner of [[Émile Zola]], which, according to Gorovei, was over-detailed and boring.<ref>Gorovei, p. 153</ref>
Upon graduation, Diamandy volunteered for service in the [[Romanian Land Forces]], spending a year and a half as an artillery man. Disliked because of his pranks ("which I for one found spirited"), he was moved to the 7th Artillery Regiment in [[Călărași]], and, because once there he complained about the mistreatment of regulars by the officers, spent several months in the disciplinary barracks.<ref>Diamandy, pp. 69–70</ref> He notes: "Just as I was ending my term as a volunteer, the captain, having learned that I had donned a civilian's outfit for a private party, ordered me in lockdown.—Lockdown meant no stove and no windows, so that's how I ended up with [[pneumonia]]."<ref name="gdy70">Diamandy, p. 70</ref>
===''L'Ère Nouvelle''=== Diamandy went on to study Law at the [[University of Paris]], but did very poorly, and was only granted half of his license; he completed the rest at [[University of Caen Lower Normandy|Caen University]].<ref name="gdy70"/> He pursued other scholarly interests, becoming a corresponding member of the ''[[Société Anthropologique]]''.<ref name="gdy70"/> He published notices on Cucuteni, as well as studies on [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]] handicrafts and a sketch of Romanian [[anthropological criminology]].<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/issue/bmsap_0301-8644_1890_num_1_1 ''Bulletins de la Société d'anthropologie de Paris, IV° Série. Tome 1, 1890''], pp. 406–408, 964–970 (republished by [https://archive.is/20120908132757/http://www.persee.fr/web/support/soon_available ''Persée'' Scientific Journals])</ref> He also completed, in 1891, the [[historical demography]] tract ''Dépopulation et repeuplement de la France'' ("The Depopulation and Repopulation of France").<ref name="tt&al84">Tamara Teodorescu, Rodica Fochi, Florența Sădeanu, Liana Miclescu, Lucreția Angheluță, ''Bibliografia românească modernă (1831–1918). Vol. II: D–K'', [[Editura științifică și enciclopedică]], Bucharest, 1986, p. 84. {{OCLC|462172635}}</ref> In parallel, he resumed his work in political journalism, with articles published in ''[[Le Journal (Paris)|Le Journal]]'', ''[[La Petite République]]'', ''La Justice'', ''Le Socialiste'', and ''L'Art Social''.<ref name="gdy70"/>
Taking over for the Romanian "revolutionary socialist" cell founded by [[Mircea Rosetti|Mircea]] and [[Vintilă Rosetti]],<ref name="cplupta36">Constantin Petculescu, "Lupta revoluționară și democratică a studențimii române. Tineri demni de tinerețea lor", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', June 1975, p. 36</ref> he joined the "internationalist revolutionary student group" of the [[Latin Quarter, Paris|Latin Quarter]], presided upon by [[Alexandre Zévaès]]. He was one of its delegates to the [[International Socialist Labor Congress of Brussels, 1891|1891 International Socialist Labor Congress]] in [[Brussels]].<ref>Livet, pp. 567–568</ref> According to his own account, he presided over the Congress proceedings.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref name="gdy70"/> In December of that year, Diamandy sided with Zévaès' moderate leadership against the radical revolutionary minority.<ref>Livet, p. 566</ref> The next year, in May, having been elected President of the student group, he was also delegated to the [[socialist feminist]] congress, where he obtained a nominal submission of socialist women to the program of a future internationalist party.<ref>Charles Sowerwine, ''Sisters or Citizens?: Women and Socialism in France since 1876'', [[Cambridge University Press]], Cambridge, 1982, pp. 68–69. {{ISBN|0-521-23484-0}}</ref> He and fellow Romanian expatriate [[Emil Racoviță]] were present at the [[Zürich Socialist and Labour Congress, 1893|Socialist and Labor Congress]], convened at [[Zürich]] in 1893.<ref name="gdy70"/>
On July 1, 1893,<ref>Călinescu, p. 657; Derfler, p. 169; Livet, p. 583</ref> Diamandy published the first issue of a "monthly for [[scientific socialism]]",<ref>Voisin, p. 405</ref> ''L'Ère Nouvelle'' ("The New Era"). It viewed itself as both a literary and a sociological review: dedicated to promoting [[literary naturalism]] and [[historical materialism]], openly provoking the reading public to explore the work of Zola, it attacked the "[[reactionary]]" critics. It also proudly called itself "eclectic".<ref>Voisin, p. 405. See also Derfler, p. 169; Livet, p. 583</ref> ''L'Ère Nouvelle'' hosted articles by [[Marxism|Marxist]] thinkers from the various countries of Europe: primarily [[Friedrich Engels]] and [[Paul Lafargue]], but also [[Georgi Plekhanov]], [[Clara Zetkin]], [[Karl Kautsky]], [[Jean Jaurès]], [[Gabriel Deville]], and [[Jules Guesde]].<ref name="cplupta36"/> Its regular contributors included [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]], the Romanian Marxist doyen, [[Duc-Quercy]], the French strike organizer, with the additional presence of Racoviță, Zévaès, [[Victor Jaclard]], [[Alexandre Millerand]], [[Adolphe Tabarant]], [[Ilya Rubanovich]], and [[Ioan Nădejde]]; [[Leó Frankel]] was the editorial secretary.<ref>Livet, p. 583. See also Diamandy, p. 70, Petrescu, pp. 80, 89</ref>
Also featured in the review, [[Georges Sorel]] was a senior [[Syndicalism|syndicalist]] with Marxist leanings, not affiliated with either Guesde's [[French Workers' Party]] (POF) or Millerand's smaller socialist circle. Diamandy and Lafargue encouraged him to extend his forays into critical social history.<ref>{{fr icon}} [[Madeleine Rebérioux]], [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/ahess_0395-2649_1964_num_19_5_421247 "Notes critiques. Début du XXe siècle: socialistes et syndicalistes français"], in ''[[Annales. Histoire, Sciences Sociales|Annales]]'', Nr. 5/1964, pp. 986, 989–990 (republished by [https://archive.is/20120908132757/http://www.persee.fr/web/support/soon_available ''Persée'' Scientific Journals]); Sternhell, pp. 68–69</ref> According to Sorel's own claim, his presence there was only made possible when non-revolutionary French socialists like Millerand had decided to boycott ''L'Ère Nouvelle''.<ref>Sternhell, p. 69</ref>
Diamandy's magazine was poorly reviewed by the sociological establishment: writing for the ''Revue Internationale de Sociologie'', [[André Voisin]] censured its "violence" and its "quite glaring partiality", but noted that some of the sociological pieces were "at the very least moderate in form".<ref>Voisin, p. 406</ref> Sorel himself recalled: "G. Diamandy [...] was at the time a ferociously [[Orthodox Marxism|orthodox Marxist]] [...]. He spent more time in the taverns of [[Montmartre]] than at University. He was a jolly good chap, entirely unreliable. I kept seeing him after that time, he was still in Mortmartre, and seemingly heading toward alcoholism."<ref>Sorel, pp. 165–166</ref> Reportedly, Diamandy was pulling pranks and farces on his socialist colleagues, even during their public functions.<ref>Gorovei, pp. 153–155</ref>
However, the publication itself had a significant, if indirect, impact on the [[French Left]]. Diamandy proudly noted that it was "France's first Marxist magazine".<ref name="gdy70"/> As historian Leslie Derfler writes, it was "the first theoretical journal in France" and an answer to ''[[Die Neue Zeit]]''; for Sorel's disciples, it also signified a turn toward a "more authentic" and "Latin" Marxism.<ref>Derfler, pp. 169–170</ref> As Sorel himself indicated a while after, this meant a split with orthodox Marxism, for the sake of "renewal".<ref>Sternhell, pp. 72–73</ref> Diamandy unwittingly enticed the conflicts between Sorel and the POF when he wrote in ''L'Ère Nouvelle'' that, according to Guesde, one need not have read Marx to become a Marxist.<ref>Sternhell, p. 72</ref>
===PSDMR=== ''L'Ère Nouvelle'' only survived for a few months, publishing its final issue in November 1894,<ref>Petrescu, p. 89</ref> before closing down in early 1895.<ref>Livet, p. 584</ref> According to Sorel, Diamandy simply "disappeared, leaving his magazine stranded".<ref name="sorel166">Sorel, p. 166</ref> Still, Diamandy managed to exert his direct influence over many other Romanian socialist students in France, from Racoviță and Nădejde to [[Alexandru Radovici]], [[Constantin Garoflid]], [[Deodat Țăranu]], [[Dimitrie Voinov]], and [[Ioan Cantacuzino]].<ref>Diamandy, p. 70; Kirițescu, p. 15</ref>
Diamandy personally sponsored the emerging socialist movement in the [[Kingdom of Romania]]. On his trips back to the country, he was welcomed as a celebrity at the socialist-run Sotir Hall, [[Bucharest]], before affiliating with the [[Romanian Social-Democratic Workers' Party]] (PSDMR).<ref>Kirițescu, pp. 14–15</ref> This Marxist group was supportive of the mainstream [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL), as the latter had promised the introduction of [[universal male suffrage]].<ref name="vdduelul">{{ro icon}} Victor Durnea, [http://www.romlit.ro/c._stere_i_duelul_su_de_la_1894 "C. Stere și duelul său de la 1894"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 1/2008</ref> At the 2nd PSDMR Congress in April 1894, Diamandy and [[Vasile Morțun]] had successfully campaigned for the introduction of such electoral demands into the party statute.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 111–112</ref> When the PNL came to power and refused to follow through with its promise, a PSDMR faction agitated in favor of the opposition [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]], even though the latter was explicitly [[right-wing]]. Writing for ''Munca'', Diamandy endorsed this view, suggesting that references to the PNL's [[progressivism]] be dropped from PSDMR's statute.<ref name="vdduelul"/>
[[File:IDEAL SOTIR, Lumea Vechĭe, 15 mai 1896.JPG|thumb|270px|The "Sotir Hall Ideal", satirized by the [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] press (May 1896): socialists and [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish Romanians]] milking a cow stamped "Romania", which is fed by an overworked peasant]] In partnership with [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]],<ref>Kirițescu, p. 17</ref> Diamandy edited for a while the PSDMR organ, ''[[Lumea Nouă]]'', exploring the possibility of returning to his home country.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref name="gdy70"/> At ''Lumea Nouă'', he put out a brochure on ''Doctrina și tactica socialistă'' ("Socialist Doctrine and Tactics").<ref name="tt&al84"/> Involved with the PSDMR chapter in [[Brăila]], he presented himself as a candidate in the [[Romanian general election, 1895|parliamentary election of 1895]], but lost.<ref>Petrescu, p. 121</ref> In 1898, he submitted to Romanian authorities the project of a "Romanian anthropological exhibition" at the [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|1900 Exposition Universelle]].<ref name="tt&al84"/><ref>"Informații", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', June 21, 1898, p. 1</ref>
Following his father's death in 1898, Diamandy made his definitive return to Romania.<ref name="gc657"/> By this time, the PSDMR was already showing the signs of a split into [[reformist]], [[Agrarian socialism|agrarian]], and orthodox-Marxist camps. Diamandy was present at secretive meetings between PSDMR founders and the agrarian group of Ion Th. Banghereanu. Also present was [[Constantin Stere]], the PSDMR's link with a left-leaning faction of the PNL, under [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]]. The reformists, distrustful of Banghereanu's sustained effort to spread socialism in rural areas, pushed for a schism: Morțun, Radovici, and, after a while, Diamandy himself, proposed that the entire PSDMR leadership leave the party and become PNL members.<ref>Ornea I, pp. 244–248, 260–262, 268; Petrescu, pp. 131–134</ref>
As Diamandy notes, the conflict became a "grave disagreement", and led him to suspend himself from the party and return to Paris.<ref name="gdy70"/> It deepened when the PNL [[Prime Minister of Romania|Premier]], [[Dimitrie Sturdza]], ordered Banghereanu's arrest on charges of sedition.<ref>Ornea I, pp. 244–248, 261–262; Petrescu, pp. 134–136</ref> Socialism was also threatened from within by disputes over [[Jewish emancipation]], which polarized the PSDMR between [[antisemitism]] and [[Jewish nationalism]]. Diamandy witnessed a violent dispute in Iași, where, he claimed, the [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish Romanian]] affiliates had been heard shouting "Down with the Romanians!"<ref>Nădejde, p. 390</ref> The antisemitic campaign was allegedly stoked by the PNL government, which sought to prove that the peasant agitation was a Jewish affair.<ref>Petrescu, p. 136</ref>
==="Generous youth"=== The moderate leadership continued to support PNL policies, even with Banghereanu jailed.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 142–143</ref> At the 6th PSDMR Congress of April 1899, Diamandy and Morțun presented a motion to transform the party into a more moderate unit, called "National Democratic" or "Progressive Democratic". According to labor historian [[Constantin Titel Petrescu]], the Congress was a sham, with many important activists absent, and with Jewish members stripped of their voting privileges, on Diamandy's own initiative.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 144–145</ref> In his own view, Diamandy was still persuaded that "intransigent" socialism could eventually work in Romania, and considered methods to prolong the PSDMR's survival.<ref>Nădejde, p. 398</ref> Speaking at the Congress, he warned that the PSDMR was already an "anti-Marxist" group dedicated to a "top-down revolution", which had only managed to set up "a socialist general staff", and could not claim to have improved the workers' lives.<ref>Petrescu, p. 145</ref> The alternative, he argued, was [[class collaboration]], which meant attracting "into our ranks all better elements of the [[bourgeoisie]]".<ref>Petrescu, p. 146</ref>
The most outspoken opponents of "National Democratic" plan were [[C. Z. Buzdugan]], [[Alexandru Ionescu (socialist militant)|Alexandru Ionescu]] and [[I. C. Frimu]], representatives of the urban underclass, who saw this as an "attack" against the PSDMR's Marxist credentials.<ref>Ornea I, pp. 267–268; Petrescu, pp. 146–150</ref> Buzdugan claimed that Diamandy had expunged the very notion of [[class conflict]] from his readings of Marxism. He himself stretched the meaning of "[[proletariat]]" to cover not just the minor class of industrial workers, but also the mass of "landless peasants"; their interests, Buzdugan concluded, could only be served by a "workers' party".<ref>Petrescu, pp. 146–148</ref> Many of those who opted for a "workers' party" resigned, while Diamandy's supporters announced that a new conference in June 1899 would transform theirs into a "sincerely democratic party".<ref>Petrescu, pp. 149–150</ref>
The April Congress effectively destroyed the PSDMR. Diamandy, Morțun and their followers, collectively referred to as "the generous youth", resigned and joined the PNL. The PSDMR that survived through June was an informal political club, whose members included Buzdugan, Ionescu, and [[Panait Zosin]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 150</ref> In later socialist historiography, this schism was seen as a victory for Stere and his [[Poporanism|Poporanist]] faction, who redirected the leftist vote toward the PNL.<ref>Ornea I, p. 268; Petrescu, pp. 143–144, 150–151</ref> According to cultural historian [[Z. Ornea]], the "generous youth" so efficiently adapted itself to the new environment, and Stere so poorly, that the rumor should be discounted.<ref>Ornea I, pp. 268–269</ref> Diamandy himself was dismissive of his contribution: "I entered the ranks of the liberal party, where I played a most silent and irrelevant part".<ref name="gdy70"/>
Following the ''[[Hallier Affair]]'', which tarnished the reputation of governing Conservatives, Diamandy took part in the unauthorized demonstrations which were broken up by [[Romanian Police|Police]].<ref>[[Constantin Bacalbașa]], ''Bucureștii de altădată. Vol. II: 1885 — 1901'', [[Universul|Editura Ziarului ''Universul'']], Bucharest, 1928, pp. 280–281</ref> He registered with the 3rd Electoral College, hoping to represent the peasants of [[Tutova County]].<ref name="tt&al84"/> Finally elected to the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Chamber (Assembly) of Deputies]] in the [[Romanian general election, 1901|1901 race]], which returned the PNL to power, Diamandy challenged [[Petre P. Carp]], the outgoing Premier, to an oratorical duel in Chamber, over the issue of [[deficit spending]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/tribunapoporului/1902/BCUCLUJ_FP_P2514_1902_006_0025.pdf "Din Camera Românieĭ"], in ''Tribuna Poporului'', February 20, 1902, pp. 1–2 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
At around that time, he married Ștefania (or Safta), the daughter of Dumitru Simionescu-Râmniceanu.<ref name="gc657"/> The latter was related by marriage to writer [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]], and a probable inspiration for the avaricious and power-hungry characters in Zamfirescu's novels.<ref>Ramona Miron, "Familia lui Duiliu Zamfirescu în ''Însemnările'' lui I. M. Dimitrescu", in Horia Dumitrescu (ed.), ''Cronica Vrancei XV'', Editura Pallas, Focșani, 2013, pp. 247–250. {{ISBN|978-973-7815-51-4}}; {{ro icon}} Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/o_scrisoare_de_la_pictorul_george_demetrescu_mirea "O scrisoare de la pictorul George Demetrescu Mirea"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 19/2008</ref> Diamandy inherited from Simionescu-Râmniceanu the large estate of [[Sascut]], but also a conflict over land with the local peasants. In May 1904, the local authorities stepped in to evacuate villagers who were demonstrating on Diamandy's property.<ref>"Informațiuni", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', June 2, 1904, p. 2</ref> The conflict was later investigated by Gorovei, the agricultural inspector for Tutova. He claims that Diamandy exploited his workers and broke all legislation.<ref>Gorovei, pp. 156–158</ref>
Diamandy's status as a rich estate owner left an enduring mark on his contemporaries. Historians and commentators made note of his eccentricity: [[Nicolae Iorga]] remembered Diamandy's "old socialism" as "a seigniorial adventure",<ref>Butnaru II, p. 178</ref> while [[Eugen Lovinescu]] simply noted that Diamandy's aristocratic airs were "incorrigible". Also according to Lovinescu, Diamandy was "a late-comer" among enthusiastic [[Francophilia|Francophiles]], one whose "mind continued to live in Paris".<ref name="el267">Lovinescu, p. 267</ref> Călinescu describes him as "an amateurish and sumptuous [[proletarian]]".<ref name="gc657"/> The same was later stated by [[Lucian Boia]], who mentions Diamandy as a "picturesque figure" and "perfect Francophile", while noting his activity among the "salon left".<ref>Boia, p. 103</ref>
===PNL dissident=== Diamandy's socialist background and dealings with the Brătianu faction brought him to the forefront during the [[1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt|1907 Peasants' Revolt]]: the fourth Sturdza cabinet, brought in to deal with the rebellion, resorted to handing out seats to Brătianu's circle, the Poporanists, and the "generous youth" alike.<ref>Ornea I, pp. 402–405</ref> Diamandy was appointed Prefect of a war zone, [[Tecuci County]], with specific orders that he was not to use the Land Forces against the peasants.<ref>Ornea I, pp. 404–405</ref> He resigned in short while, citing health reasons.<ref name="gc657"/> As he put it, in 1912: "It was during the revolts that I contracted infectious [[influenza]], which is still killing me about 6 times each year. The sedentary life that comes with disease is what pushed me to writing, and thus, out of boredom and being exasperated with my disease, I began collaborating with [the National Liberal newspapers] ''[[Voința Națională]]'' and ''[[Viitorul]]''."<ref>Diamandy, pp. 70–71</ref>
The interval also prompted him to work on a fictionalized [[diary]], ''Ne om'' ("No Man"), which records his anxiety in front of disease and impending doom.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> It saw print in 1908, with the editorial branch of ''[[L'Indépendence Roumaine]]'' daily.<ref name="tt&al84"/> He had a prolific activity as a publicist, with articles in the central press, but also with political brochures that he signed using various pseudonyms—''Gh. Despina'', ''Ion Marvila'', and ''Ne om''.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> Following the [[Romanian general election, 1907|1907 election]], reconfirmed as deputy, Diamandy and the other "generous" parliamentarians became key players in the transition from a Sturdza cabinet to the first of seven Brătianu administrations.<ref>Ornea I, p. 427–428</ref> When it came about, in 1908, it was largely seen by the Conservatives as a covert socialist government, not least of all because of ambiguous statements made by Stere and Diamandy.<ref>Ornea I, p. 476</ref>
The fear of radicalized socialism peaked in December 1909, when Brǎtianu was attacked and wounded by Gheorghe Stoenescu, a deranged worker with [[Anarchism in Romania|anarchist]] sympathies. The opposition asked Diamandy and Ioan Nădejde to clarify whether they were still Marxists; they confirmed that they still viewed themselves as [[Dialectical materialism|dialectical materialists]], explaining their perspective as a kind of "[[Darwinism]]".<ref>Ornea I, pp. 522, 538</ref> Diamandy gave his endorsement to Stere's project of [[Land reform in Romania|land reform]], which was resisted by the Conservatives, as well as by Brătianu and Nădejde.<ref>Ornea II, pp. 30–31</ref>
Diamandy also believed it necessary to criticize the PNL from within. According to a 1911 retrospective in ''[[Noua Revistă Română]]'', he proved himself "an ''[[enfant terrible]]'' of our politics": "He kept on admonishing Mr. Brătianu, even though it was him who had given him an eligible deputy seat. It was either that Mr. Brătianu is not democratic enough; or that Mr. Brătianu cannot organize his own party; neither of these seemed to please Mr. Diamandy. And Mr. Diamandy would always make sure to voice his opinion at the most inappropriate times."<ref name="acccopii97">A.C.C., "Noutăți. Doi copii teribili în politica noastră", in ''[[Noua Revistă Română]]'', Nr. 7/1911, p. 97</ref>
In 1910, Diamandy published his first works in drama: a four-act play, ''Tot înainte'' ("Carry On"), and a "dramatic sketch", ''Bestia'' ("The Beast").<ref name="tt&al84"/><ref name="gc1014">Călinescu, p. 1014</ref> The latter was produced by the [[National Theater Bucharest]], with [[Maria Filotti]] in the central role, and attracted much attention with its "daring subject".<ref>Livescu, pp. 102, 125</ref> Diamandy did not join the [[Romanian Writers' Society]], objecting to its antisemitism, and suggesting, in a letter to ''Noua Revistă Română'', that the professional association had admitted talentless authors.<ref>"Cestiuni actuale. Evreii și literatura", in ''[[Noua Revistă Română]]'', Nr. 16/1910, pp. 245–246</ref> In articles he wrote for ''[[Facla]]'' and ''Semnalul'' newspapers, Diamandy openly advocated Jewish emancipation, against nationalist objections.<ref>[[Nicolae Iorga]], ''Acţiunea militară a României. În Bulgaria cu ostaşii noştri'', [[Editura Socec]], Bucharest, 1914, p. 19</ref>
===''Revista Democrației Române''=== In 1910, Diamandy founded the weekly ''Revista Democrației Române'' ("Review of Romanian Democracy"), which, as a cultural and sociological venture, suggested a program of [[Ethnography|ethnographic]] studies in the Romanian villages,<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> and printed an edition of ''Bestia''.<ref name="tt&al84"/><ref name="gc1014"/> Politically, ''Revista Democrației Române'' coagulated inner-PNL dissidence, accusing Brătianu of having turned [[reactionary]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Sorin Radu, [http://istorie.uab.ro/publicatii/colectia_auash/annales_4_5/17.pdf "Liberalii și problema reformei electorale în România (1866 — 1914) (I)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425080928/http://istorie.uab.ro/publicatii/colectia_auash/annales_4_5/17.pdf |date=2012-04-25 }}, in the [[1 Decembrie 1918 University, Alba Iulia|1 December University of Alba Iulia]] ''Annales Universitatis Apulensis, Series Historica'', Nr. 4–5, 2000–2001, pp. 140, 142–143</ref> It hosted Diamandy's thoughts about reforming the [[1866 Constitution of Romania|1866 Constitution]]: although he no longer demanded universal suffrage, he still saw it as a historical necessity farther down the line.<ref name="nrrsvonul105-106">M., "Noutăți. Svonul despre revizuirea Constituției", in ''[[Noua Revistă Română]]'', Nr. 8/1910, pp. 105–106</ref> Also featured was his maverick proposal to merge the breakaway [[Conservative-Democratic Party]], a junior ally, into the PNL. These ideas were derided by the Conservative-Democrats at ''Noua Revistă Română'',<ref name="acccopii97"/> who also noted that Diamandy's proposals were conspicuously serving the politically insignificant "generous youth".<ref name="nrrsvonul105-106"/>
Stere and the "generous ones" were noted contributors to the magazine, as were [[Constantin Banu]], [[Ioan Bianu]], [[Gheorghe Gh. Mârzescu]], [[Constantin Alimănișteanu]], [[Ioan Alexandru Brătescu-Voinești]], and some of the committed Marxists.<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', p. 532</ref> Outside this circle, Diamandy found himself isolated on the political scene, and was no longer proposed for an eligible seat in the [[Romanian general election, 1911|elections of 1911]],<ref name="acccopii97"/> presenting a full report on his activities to his Tutova constituents.<ref name="tt&al84"/> ''Revista Democrației Române'' survived until 1912, by which time Diamandy had decided to stay away from political journalism, "since I only see fit to write as my conscience tells me to".<ref name="gdy71">Diamandy, p. 71</ref>
Another of his plays, ''Dolorosa'', was taken up by the National Theater in 1911.<ref name="gc1014"/> The same year, Diamandy prefaced the collected works of a deceased socialist poet, [[Ion Păun-Pincio]].<ref name="tt&al84"/><ref>Petrescu, p. 114</ref> By 1912, when his political satire ''Rațiunea de stat'' ("The Reason of State") was published in ''[[Flacăra]]'' review<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> and taken up by Comoedia Troupe, Diamandy had been elected President of the Romanian Theatrical Society.<ref name="cgmînsemn567">{{ro icon}} C. Georgescu Munteanu, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/luceafarul/1912/BCUCLUJ_FP_280091_1912_011_028.pdf "Însemnări"], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 28/1912, p. 567 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> However, Diamandy complained that his works were ignored by the National Theater, despite good referrals from writers [[Iacob Negruzzi]] and Zamfirescu.<ref name="gdy71"/> Alongside [[Radu D. Rosetti]], he formed a Literary Circle at the rival Comoedia.<ref>"Sărbătorirea maestrului Caragiale. Festivalul de la Teatrul Comoedia", in ''Românul (Arad)'', Nr. 26/1912, p. 7</ref> Eventually joining the Writers' Society in 1911,<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> he left it in 1913, but returned by popular demand in 1914.<ref name="vipssr618">[[Victor Ion Popa]], "Societatea Scriitorilor Români", in ''Boabe de Grâu'', Nr. 10/1934, p. 618</ref>
Diamandy bought himself a [[yacht]], ''Spargeval'' ("Breakwave"), and sailed the [[Black Sea]] coast, writing on other plays.<ref>Călinescu, p. 657; Gorovei, pp. 158–159. See also Diamandy, p. 71</ref> Soon, his attention focused on the "[[Eastern Question]]". In 1910, he returned from an extended trip through the [[Ottoman Empire]], which is recorded in his [[Travel literature|travelogue]], ''Impressions de Turquie''.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref name="tt&al84"/> On his way through [[Babadag]], a traditional [[Turks of Romania|Turkish]]-and-[[Islam in Romania|Islamic]] center in Romania, Diamandy refurbished the local ''[[Khanqah|Tekke]]'', planting a new votive inscription over the tomb of Gazi Ali.<ref>Goran I. Cialicoff, notes to "Din descrierea călătoriei lui Evliia-Celebi", in ''Arhiva Dobrogei'', Vol. II, 1919, p. 143</ref>
Turning to nationalism during the [[Second Balkan War]], Diamandy gave morale-supporting lectures to infantrymen of the Land Forces,<ref>Baiculescu ''et al.'', p. 467; Butnaru I, pp. 142–143</ref> having already prefaced a textbook of [[Military education and training|military pedagogy]], by Colonel Gheorghe Șuer.<ref name="tt&al84"/> In June 1913, he also wrote the foreword to a [[social geography]] tract by Major G. A. Dabija. The work as a whole was probably the first in history to justify Romania's colonization of [[Southern Dobruja]], formerly in the [[Kingdom of Bulgaria]].<ref>Lascu, pp. 76–80</ref> As later noted by Dabija, Diamandy's "unofficial" penmanship was required to divert attention from this being the expansionist policy of a Conservative government.<ref>Lascu, pp. 76, 79</ref>
===National Theater Director=== In 1913, under a PNL government headed by Ion I. C. Brătianu, [[Ministry of Culture and National Patrimony|Culture Minister]] [[Ion G. Duca]] appointed Diamandy Director of the National Theater. As Duca would claim in his memoirs, this was only "to fulfill one of [Diamandy's] dreams"—Diamandy, Duca writes, had "an incorrigible mania for being or seeming original."<ref>Butnaru II, p. 178; Duca, p. 211</ref> He was only National Theater director for a few months, being replaced by his ''Revista Democrației Române'' colleague Brătescu-Voinești before the end of the 1913–1914 season; he returned for a second term later in 1914.<ref>Massoff, pp. 215–218. See also Livescu, pp. 127, 129</ref>
The time he spent in office only served to aggravate his colleagues in the theatrical business.<ref>Boia, p. 236; Massoff, p. 320</ref> One of them, [[Ioan Massoff]], recalled that Diamandy had made a habit of citing his heart troubles to avoid seeing any of his subordinates, simply dictating his reform-minded wishes to them by proxy.<ref>Massoff, pp. 320–321</ref> Reportedly, Diamandy sacked the actor [[Vasile Leonescu]] for spite: Leonescu had criticized ''Rațiunea de stat'' as "unworthy of being staged by Romania's top venue."<ref>Massoff, pp. 333–334</ref> Another actor, [[Ion Livescu]], recalled that, although "an enlightened democrat", and "well inspired" in his choices for the repertoire, Diamandy played the part of an authoritarian, and only communicated through his secretary, [[Marin Simionescu-Râmniceanu]]. However, Livescu believes that Diamandy had good cause to ignore complaints and avoid quarrels.<ref>Livescu, pp. 129–130</ref>
By that stage in his career, Diamandy was contemplating the creation of a Romanian "[[Théâtre du Peuple|People's Theater]]" for the benefit of peasants, the news of which sparked ridicule in the urban press.<ref>[[George Ranetti|Kiriak Napadarjan]], "Teatrul la sate", in ''[[Furnica (magazine)|Furnica]]'', Nr. 32/1907, p. 2</ref> His own work for the stage underwent a change of style: also in 1914, he published in ''Flacăra'' the localized "heroic comedy" ''Chemarea codrului'' ("Call of the Woods"), written in the format of a ''[[comédie en vaudeville]]''.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 657, 1014</ref> It premiered at his own National Theater, with Filotti as the female lead,<ref>Livescu, p. 131</ref> and was an instant favorite of the public.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> The [[Fantasy literature|fantasy]] format of the play satisfied Diamandy, who went on to publish other plays and dramatic fragments: ''Strună cucoane'' ("Hold on, Sire"), ''Hămăiță'' ("Barker"), ''Regina Lia'' ("Queen Lia"), and the [[libretto]] for a children's opera, ''Gheorghiță Făt-Frumos'' ("Gheorghiță Prince Charming"), set to music by [[Alfons Castaldi]].<ref name="ffmoșierul"/>
After the outbreak of [[World War I]], Romania opted to preserve her neutrality, with public opinion divided between Francophile and [[Germanophilia|Germanophile]] groups, respectively supportive of the [[Allies of World War I|Entente countries]] and the [[Central Powers]]. Francophilia showed up in his articles for various literary and political reviews, including his one-time contribution to ''[[Versuri și Proză]]'' magazine (September 1, 1914).<ref>[[Angelo Mitchievici]], ''Decadență și decadentism în contextul modernității românești și europene'', [[Editura Curtea Veche]], Bucharest, 2011, p. 145. {{ISBN|978-606-588-133-4}}</ref> This political stance was probably a factor in his 1914 election as president of the Writers' Society,<ref>Boia, pp. 102–104</ref> as was his status as Theater manager.<ref name="vipssr618"/> He combined both assignments, collecting grants for the writers through Theater benefits, and selling Romanian books through a special booth in the Theater's foyer.<ref name="vipssr618"/>
Diamandy's mandate came to an end in August 1915,<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> when he assigned his seat to [[Alexandru Mavrodi]].<ref>Massoff, p. 219</ref> As Livescu notes: "when it seemed to him that there would not be many people who could understand him [...], he put his hat on, and, having just lectured us so very passionately about that France of his, left us all, with a cold and jerky salute from the top of the stairs: 'Good day y'all!'"<ref>Livescu, p. 130</ref>
===World War I strategist and soldier=== [[File:Manifestation franco-roumaine, La Revue Hebdomadaire, 16 jan 1915.jpg|thumb|360px|The Romanian delegation and its hosts in Paris, January 1915. Diamandy is seated, front row, center, between Ambassador [[Ioan Lahovary]] (to his left) and French historian Georges Lacour-Gáyet. Behind them, from left: [[Stéphen Pichon]], [[Milenko Radomar Vesnić]], [[Denys Cochin]], [[Athos Romanos]], [[Emil Costinescu]], [[Jean Richepin]], [[Ioan Cantacuzino]], [[Joseph Aulneau]], and [[Dimitar Stanchov]].]] Diamandy's enthusiasm for intervention was held back by reports that Romania risked going into war without proper weapons and ammunition.<ref>Butnaru I, pp. 143, 146; Duca, p. 134</ref> With this in mind, he and [[Constantin Istrati]] were sent to Italy by Premier Brătianu, and successfully negotiated a treaty of mutual assistance between the two neutral countries.<ref name="abI143">Butnaru I, p. 143</ref> He also visited traditionally-hostile Bulgaria, and claimed to have obtained assurances from [[Prime Minister of Bulgaria|Prime Minister]] [[Vasil Radoslavov]] that she would not [[Bulgaria in World War I|join the Central Powers]].<ref name="abI143"/> His brother Constantin Diamandy, noted for his highly optimistic combative stance and his martial attire,<ref>Butnaru I, pp. 136, 146; Duca, p. 11</ref> became one of Brătianu's confidants. During his diplomatic missions, he had also informed the government, reassuringly, about the goings-on in Bulgaria, and acted as liaison with the [[Russian Empire]].<ref>Butnaru I, ''passim''</ref>
For a while, Diamandy was affiliated with the trans-party "National Action", which, under [[Take Ionescu]] and [[Nicolae Filipescu]], sought to bring Romania into the Entente. In January 1915, he was the group's envoy to France,<ref>Ornea II, p. 77</ref> but acted as an informal delegate for Brătianu.<ref name="abI143-144">Butnaru I, pp. 143–144</ref> He was welcomed by the Franco–Romanian Friendship Committee and by [[Paul Deschanel]] personally. His erstwhile associate, [[Georges Sorel]], commented that Deschanel must have been misinformed: "[Diamandy] must really be thinking that Paris is a capital for the rent-seekers, since now they take him seriously. If Romania had had an honest intent to strike a deal with us, it would have surely picked herself some other negotiator. Evidently P. Deschanel was not aware of Diamandy's character."<ref name="sorel166"/>
Diamandy also had a meeting with [[Raymond Poincaré]], the [[President of France]]. He may have informed him about Radoslavov's promises, which Diamandy still took for granted, and which may explain Poincaré's overly confident support for Romania in later Entente conferences.<ref name="abI143-144"/> However, the talk also covered the issue of Romania's grievances toward Russia, which still prevented her for entering the war. He introduced this enigma to Poincaré: "Romania looks forward to France's victory and to Russia's defeat" (''see [[Franco-Russian Alliance]]'').<ref>[[François Fejtő]], ''Requiem pour un empire défunt. Histoire de la destruction de l'Autriche-Hongrie'', ÉDIMA/Lieu Commun & [[Éditions du Seuil]], Paris, 1993, p. 57. {{ISBN|2-02-014674-6}}</ref> At one of the banquets in his honor, Diamandy divulged the existence of a parallel [[France–Romania relations|Franco–Romanian alliance]],<ref>Butnaru I, p. 144</ref> and stressed "that R[o]mania's entry into the war would result in the conflict's end."<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/58327868/ "Thinks Rumania Will End the War"], in ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', January 11, 1915, p. 5</ref>
Diamandy gave a public report on the world conflict and how it fit with Romania's national interest at the National Liberal Party Center of Studies.<ref name="tt&al84"/> It was published, in 1916, with assistance from the [[Romanian Academy]].<ref name="abI146">Butnaru I, p. 146</ref> The same year, he prefaced (as ''Giorgio Diamandy'') Federico Valerio Ratti's monograph on "Latin Romania", published in [[Florence]] by I Libri d'Oggi.<ref>''Bulletin of the New York Public Library, Vol. 23. January to December 1919'', Astor, Lenox and Tilden Foundations, New York City, 1919, p. 68</ref> Other such pieces were taken up by various newspapers and magazines, including ''[[Universul]]'', ''[[L'Indépendence Roumaine]]'', and ''[[Rampa (Romanian magazine)|Rampa]]''.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> He also put out a complete collection of his [[novella]]s.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref name="tt&al84"/>
Returning to Chamber after the [[Romanian general election, 1914|1914 elections]], Diamandy participated in the heated sessions of December 1915. He voiced the mainstream opinion of the PNL in open disputes with the Conservative [[Petre P. Carp]]. He rejected Carp's fears that a victorious Russia looked set to occupy the [[Danube Delta]], but also noted that he himself had reserves about bringing Romania into the war, and made public his resignation from the "National Action".<ref name="dincamera3">{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/36771/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_PIV1902_1916_026_0001.pdf "Din Camera română"], in ''Unirea'', January 1, 1916, p. 3 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> This effectively returned him to the PNL's mainstream, where he continued to campaign in favor of going to war.<ref>Ornea II, pp. 103–107</ref> Nevertheless, Diamandy also supported his former ally, Stere, who was being heckled by the other deputies for suggesting that an alliance against Russia was in Romania's benefit.<ref name="dincamera3"/><ref>Ornea II, pp. 104–107</ref>
Eventually, in summer 1916, Premier Brătianu discarded his reservations, and Romania [[Treaty of Bucharest (1916)|entered the war as an Entente country]]. While Constantin became tasked with ensuring a direct Russian military involvement and military aid for the [[Romania in World War I|Romanian Front]],<ref>Butnaru I, pp. 147–149</ref> George again volunteered for military service. He was reputedly enrolled as a private, but was seen traveling with his own [[Batman (military)|orderly]].<ref>Gorovei, pp. 159–160</ref> He was detached to the [[Second Army (Romania)|Second Army]] commandment in the [[Southern Carpathians]], where he held conference with General [[Alexandru Averescu]] and other officers. Averescu remembered him as a shady figure, not worthy of his trust, and noted in particular Diamandy's ideas about using [[expanding bullet]]s against the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]] (which had reportedly initiated their use in combat).<ref>Averescu, pp. 15–16, 88–89</ref> Diamandy saw action in the front-line trenches, but was still plagued by his lung and heart problems, and was eventually sent to a hospital behind the lines.<ref>Butnaru I, p. 148</ref> By then, the Diamandys' forecasts about Bulgarian neutrality and Romanian readiness for war proved misguided, with Romania suffering a scathing defeat in the [[Battle of Turtucaia]].<ref>Butnaru I, p. 147</ref>
===Labor Party=== After losing the [[Battle of Bucharest]] in December 1916, the Romanian Land Forces withdrew into [[Moldavia]], which, with Russian help, they defended against renewed Central Powers offensives. Diamandy was also moved to Iași, the provisional capital, where Brătianu's government and the Parliament had relocated. He took back his Chamber seat, and, as the poor management of war weakened support for Brătianu, went on public record with his criticism.<ref>Duca, pp. 133–137</ref>
The [[February Revolution]] in Russia reopened the path toward radical socializing reforms, and pushed Diamandy back into socialist politics. Brătianu promised land reform and a new electoral law, but Diamandy and other dissenting PNL-ists were not appeased: they claimed that the government had lost its "moral right" to apply such legislation, and obstructed it repeatedly.<ref>Ornea II, pp. 167–168. See also Gorovei, p. 161</ref> According to Duca's hostile account, the February Revolution gave Diamandy the illusion that time had come for him "to play a great role", and that the "tyrannical" Brătianu was an embarrassment for the [[Russian Provisional Government|Russian democracy]].<ref name="Duca, p.172">Duca, p. 172</ref> Duca also claims that, despite his "laughable exhibitions" in favor of land reform, Diamandy could never conceive of completely redistributing property from the landowners to the peasants.<ref>Butnaru II, p. 178; Duca, pp. 196, 198, 200–201</ref>
By April 1917, Diamandy had formed his own [[parliamentary party]], called [[Labor Party (Romania)|Labor Party]] (''Partidul Muncei''). It had the radical agrarianist [[Nicolae L. Lupu]] for a co-chairman, with [[Grigore Iunian]], [[Ioan Cantacuzino]], [[Grigore Trancu-Iași]], [[Constantin Ion Parhon]], [[Mihail Macavei]], [[Grigore Filipescu]]<ref>Duca, pp. 174–175, 180, 187–189; Ornea II, p. 167; Petrescu, p. 312; Popescu, pp. 21–22</ref><ref name="rpenigma2">{{ro icon}} Radu Petrescu, [http://www.contrafort.md/numere/enigma-ilie-c-t-r-u-ii "Enigma Ilie Cătărău (II)"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009200046/http://www.contrafort.md/numere/enigma-ilie-c-t-r-u-ii |date=October 9, 2013 }}, in ''[[Contrafort]]'', Nr. 7–8/2012</ref> and [[Alexandru Slătineanu]]<ref name="gifînszil">{{ro icon}} Gheorghe I. Florescu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/FLORESCUnov4.html "Însemnări zilnice din anii Primului Război Mondial"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', November 2004</ref> as regular members. Diamandy himself authored the central manifesto, published as a brochure.<ref name="tt&al84"/> As Duca writes, the ailing dramatist was parading in a socialist's uniform: "a sort of Russian worker's blouse, his boots on, quite like an authentic comrade just arrived from some [[Soviet (council)|soviet]]".<ref name="Duca, p.172"/> He was "evidently ridiculous", "acutely megalomaniac", driven to "a pathological state" by the urgency of his heart disease.<ref>Duca, p. 176</ref> The [[Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (Romania)|Minister of Agriculture]], [[Gheorghe Gh. Mârzescu]], was also disturbed by Diamandy's behavior, writing: "George Diamandi, thinking about ways to support the ideas of the Labor Party, born from personal ambitions stoked by the Russian revolution, imagined that he should necessarily show up in Chamber in [[Kosovorotka|Tolstoy's costume]]. This operetta thing is produced for the benefit of peasants."<ref name="gifînszil"/>
In his private diaries, General Averescu recalls his meeting with an anxious [[King of Romania|King]] [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand]] in the small town of [[Moinești]]. The monarch looked into "the growth of a socialist movement in our country", and had left Iași because "socialists and young liberals, under G. Diamandy, are supposedly in contact with the Russian revolutionaries".<ref>Averescu, p. 156</ref> The account is also supported by Duca. According to him, Diamandy and Lupu had revived their contacts with the old socialists, as well as with [[Socialist Revolutionary Party|Russian Esers]], with whose backing they intended to set up a Romanian "democratic government"; their project for a revolution was bogged down when the "pragmatic" Russians discovered that the Labor Party was politically insignificant and "oligarchic".<ref>Duca, pp. 173, 176–178, 180</ref> The Labor faction also branched into neighboring [[Bessarabia]], using the revolutionary agent [[Ilie Cătărău]] for an emissary.<ref name="rpenigma2"/> Nevertheless, the Laborites supported the calls for order, reacting against Russian soldiers and Romanian civilians who demanded a "Romanian republic".<ref>Gorovei, pp. 160–161</ref>
According to [[Arthur Gorovei]], the Labor Party should be regarded as George Diamandy's "final prank".<ref>Gorovei, p. 161</ref> In June 1917, following the [[Battle of Mărăști|renewed offensive]] of the Central Powers, Diamandy became a refugee to Russia,<ref>Butnaru II, p. 178; Duca, p. 205</ref> where his brother Constantin was [[Romanian Ambassador to Russia|Romanian Ambassador]]. He was trapped on Russian territory during the [[October Revolution]], events which his brother downplayed in his reports to Brătianu.<ref>Butnaru II, p. 179</ref> The Revolution took Russia out of the war and signaled the start of a [[Romania–Russia relations|Russian–Romanian diplomatic war]]: Constantin was held in captivity by the [[Council of People's Commissars]], and eventually expelled.<ref name="msrdamandy"/><ref>Butnaru II, pp. 180–182</ref>
===Death and aftermath=== George Diamandy fled to the [[White Sea]] port of [[Arkhangelsk]], where he embarked on the ship ''Kursk'', bound for France. ''Kursk'' also transported some 3,000 returning members of the [[Czechoslovak Legion]] and some 300 French governesses.<ref name="gc657"/> On the stormy night of December 27, 1917, off the coast of [[Shetland]], Diamandy suffered a fatal attack of [[Angina pectoris|angina]]<ref name="gc657"/><ref name="ffmoșierul"/> (or [[myocardial infarction]]).<ref>Butnaru II, p. 179; Duca, p. 205</ref> As noted by Călinescu: "his coffin was [[Burial at sea|buried at sea]], while a choir formed by hundreds of Czechs sang, as an homage."<ref>Călinescu, p. 657. See also Butnaru II, p. 179</ref>
Diamandy's death was received with indifference by the Germanophiles and wearied intellectuals in Bucharest. In his obituary for ''Scena'' magazine, dramatist [[A. de Herz]] referred to the deceased as an unpatriotic man of "ferocious egotism", claiming that his leadership of the National Theater had been "dismal".<ref>Boia, p. 236</ref> The mood changed soon after the [[First Armistice at Compiègne|November 1918 Armistice]], which sealed the Entente's victory on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]], and returned Romanian Francophiles to high favor. Diamandy's last play, ''Una dintr-o mie'' ("One in a Thousand"), was performed by the National Theater in 1919.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref>Călinescu, p. 1014; Massoff, p. 225</ref>
Presided upon by Lupu, the Labor Party continued to be active in the opposition, fought against the signing of [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|peace with the Central Powers]], and presented its own candidates in the [[Romanian general election, 1918|1918 election]].<ref>Ornea II, pp. 209, 212–213</ref> Some of its members were already defecting to the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's League]] or rejoining the PNL, while the Laborite leadership considered an alliance with the [[Socialist Party of Romania|Socialist Party]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 313. See also Popescu, pp. 22–24</ref> It eventually merged into Stere's [[Peasants' Party (Romania)|Peasants' Party]], which became one of the PNL's leading opponents in the early interwar period.<ref>Ornea II, pp. 213–214; Petrescu, p. 313; Popescu, p. 22</ref> Stere himself rekindled memories of Diamandy by making him a secondary character, "Raul Dionide", in the 1930s novel ''În preajma revoluției''.<ref>[[Ovid Crohmălniceanu]], ''Literatura română între cele două războaie mondiale'', Vol. I, [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1972, p. 379. {{OCLC|490001217}}</ref>
The marriage between George and Ștefania Diamandy produced a son, Ion "Iancușor" (1905–1935),<ref name="gc657"/><ref name="msrdamandy"/> and two daughters, Georgeta and Anca. Unusually, they would both be successively married to the same man: aviator [[Constantin Cantacuzino (aviator)|Constantin "Bâzu" Cantacuzino]], son of the Conservative politico [[Mihail G. Cantacuzino]] and of [[Maruca Cantacuzino|Maruca Rosetti]].<ref name="gc657"/><ref name="msrdamandy"/> Georgeta's marriage to Cantacuzino produced one daughter, the writer [[Oana Orlea]] (Maria-Ioana Cantacuzino).<ref name="gc657"/><ref name="msrdamandy"/><ref>{{ro icon}} [[Alex. Ștefănescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/cine_este_oana_orlea "Cine este Oana Orlea?"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 42/2011</ref>
==Plays and prose== Diamandy is often regarded as a very minor contributor to [[Romanian literature]]. According to Lovinescu, he was as much a "dilettante" here as in archeology and socialism, "cerebral", but lacking "artistic intuition".<ref>Lovinescu, pp. 267, 268</ref> The same was noted by writer [[Florin Faifer]], who assesses that Diamandy "was not in fact a virtuoso" of drama, losing himself in musings that range "from art to politics and the economy."<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> C. Georgescu Munteanu of ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'' condemned ''Rațiunea de stat'' as "a pointless work", the dramatization of such "a commonplace fact" that the public could not bring itself to applaud it.<ref name="cgmînsemn567"/> ''Una dintr-o mie'' also evidenced this problematic style. According to Faifer, its humorous intent was "tortured, burdened by vulgarities."<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> As noted in 2007 by historian Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, Diamandy the dramatist had been "entirely forgotten".<ref name="msrdamandy"/>
Inspired by the works of [[Henrik Ibsen]],<ref name="gc657"/> ''Tot înainte'' depicts life in the fictional [[arms industry]] of [[Clermont-Ferrand]]. The young industrialist Jean Héquet intervenes to save the livelihoods of his employees, taking over management from his intransigent father.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> As a political manifesto, it seemingly favors [[class collaboration]], but, as Călinescu notes, "seems to be rather [[Communism|communistic]] in spirit."<ref name="gc657"/> According to Massoff, it was read as "a play with socialist undertones".<ref>Massoff, p. 320</ref> In ''Bestia'', called by Călinescu "an intellectual play with a confusing exposition",<ref name="gc657"/> the divorcée Ninetta Coman displays her seemingly visceral [[misandry]]. Her viciousness is confronted by an idealistic husband, who (Faifer notes) is an "artificial" character.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> Towards the end of the play, Ninetta is revealed to have been the long-suffering victim of sexual violence, and to have undergone a voluntary [[hysterectomy]].<ref>Călinescu, p. 657; Lovinescu, p. 267</ref> In ''Dolorosa'', Lovinescu reads echoes from [[Gabriele D'Annunzio|D'Annunzio]].<ref name="el267"/> It shows the duel of wits between two painters and a woman of their company: she loves the one who does not love her back.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref>Lovinescu, pp. 267–268</ref>
Critics were generally more lenient toward ''Chemarea codrului''. Massoff calls it "one of the good Romanian plays".<ref>Massoff, p. 321</ref> Lovinescu welcomed its imprecision, which parted with the staples of [[historical drama]] while preserving "the national atmosphere"; the result being "a [[hajduk]] legend" admitting "poetry and idealism."<ref>Lovinescu, p. 268</ref> Călinescu sees ''Chemarea'' as Diamandy's "only reasonably valid play", but "false" in content and "embarrassing" with its depiction of sexual controversy.<ref name="gc657"/> Localized in medieval [[Ștefan cel Mare, Bacău|Rădeana]], it alludes to the rape of Anca, a virtuous young woman, by marauding [[Tatars of Romania|Tatars]]. Although dishonored under the [[shame culture]] of that period, she is defended by the young nobleman, Ioniță, who elopes with her into the surrounding woods.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/><ref>Călinescu, p. 657; Lovinescu, p. 268</ref>
According to Faifer, Diamandy's other writings display a taste for "the picturesque" and "the unforeseen".<ref name="ffmoșierul"/> These include ''Ne om'', but also his travelogue, his hunting stories, and his novellas. The latter works show [[Bohemianism|bohemian society]] and the rural elite at their most decadent, subject to illusions and violent passions.<ref name="ffmoșierul"/>
